conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows (A, B, C, D) cast by objects change in position and size when the light source moves to the back-right.
All shadows will swing forward-left across the ground because the light now comes from the opposite corner (back-right).
Shadow A (from the nail) will shift the farthest, appearing farther forward and left from the nail’s base.
Shadow B (from the pie) will also move forward-left, ending up partly in front of and to the left of the pie.
Shadow C (from the roll of bandage) will slide noticeably to the left (toward the bright floor patch) and a bit forward.
Shadow D (from the ring) will travel forward-left as well, ending up near the lower-left edge of the ring’s original spot.
Because the new light position is farther from the objects than before, every shadow becomes slightly smaller and sharper.
The amount of shrinkage is most noticeable on the taller objects (nail and bandage roll) and least noticeable on the low ring.

After the light source is moved to the back-right, every shadow shifts forward-left and becomes a bit smaller and clearer, with the largest positional swing occurring for the tallest object (A) and the smallest size change for the flattest object (D).
